issues.title: Do we want one spec or several?
issues.author: mprorock
issues.body:
Open question for discussion:
1) Single spec covering PQC signatures and each scheme as a section (this is totally fine for incubation independent of where things shake out)
2) One spec per scheme
3) one spec for broad PQC usage with JOSE and then one spec per scheme that reference that spec

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
For sure to start, we should assume 1 spec... and have it cover key and signature serializations in JSON and CBOR.

I don't think we get a big benefit for splitting CBOR and JSON up, and there is precedent for doing them at the same time... see https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8812.

I also don't think we get a huge benefit from splitting by crypto system... although I think that could be argued against.

In general, we are defining serializations for lattice and hash based schemes... splitting along those lines would make sense... IF each list was very long and needed a lot of special treatment... but since we are really only looking at serializations I don't think that will be the case... we are not here to define crypto, only serializations of defined crypto.

comments.author: brownoxford
comments.body: I did a quick test and, should we decide to go that route, the build framework will work on any and all `draft*.md` files in the repo.

issues.title: Embedded SVGs are problematic
issues.author: brownoxford
issues.body:
Embedded SVGs cause the build process to produce many errors, and omit the math entirely from TXT versions of the draft:

```
3.3.1.  Generate

   (Artwork only available as svg: spec/key-gen.svg)

                                  Figure 1
```

Can we refactor this into text format? I took a look at some other specs, e.g., [bbs+](https://identity.foundation/bbs-signature/draft-bbs-signatures.html), and they seem to use text for the math (doesn't look great though).

issues.title: References to CRYSTALS-Dilithium cause "Too Wide" warnings
issues.author: brownoxford
issues.body:
These references are currently included as untyped code blocks which `mmark` converts into `<artwork>` elements.  Currently, this is resulting in a number of warnings regarding elements and sections being "too wide" by `xml2rfc`:

```
/Users/cabernet/Documents/src/github.com/brownoxford/post-quantum-signatures.git/draft-post-quantum-jose.xml(256): Warning: Artwork too wide, reducing indentation from 3 to 2
/Users/cabernet/Documents/src/github.com/brownoxford/post-quantum-signatures.git/draft-post-quantum-jose.xml(287): Warning: Artwork too wide, reducing indentation from 3 to 0
/Users/cabernet/Documents/src/github.com/brownoxford/post-quantum-signatures.git/draft-post-quantum-jose.xml(284): Warning: Section too wide, reducing indentation from 0 to 0
/Users/cabernet/Documents/src/github.com/brownoxford/post-quantum-signatures.git/draft-post-quantum-jose.xml(178): Warning: Section too wide, reducing indentation from 0 to 0
/Users/cabernet/Documents/src/github.com/brownoxford/post-quantum-signatures.git/draft-post-quantum-jose.xml(175): Warning: Section too wide, reducing indentation from 0 to 0
/Users/cabernet/Documents/src/github.com/brownoxford/post-quantum-signatures.git/draft-post-quantum-jose.xml(66): Warning: Section too wide, reducing indentation from 0 to 0
/Users/cabernet/Documents/src/github.com/brownoxford/post-quantum-signatures.git/draft-post-quantum-jose.xml(39): Warning: Middle too wide, reducing indentation from 0 to 0
```

This can be easily solved by converting these references to blockquotes instead of code blocks, which actually seems more appropriate in this case.

issues.title: JSON code samples contain lines longer than 69 chars
issues.author: brownoxford
issues.body: `xml2rfc` complains about lines longer than 69 characters. This can be fixed by wrapping lines as described in [RFC 8792](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8792).

issues.title: JWK and JWA Fields
issues.author: OR13
issues.body:
Consider:

```js
kty: 'PQK',
alg: 'CRYDI',
pset: '3',
x: 'mVahKoVifK...'
```

Do we really want the `pset` value encoded like this?

JWA / JWK layers are meant to abstract complexity from lower level crypto.

IMO, we should be registering thing such that you can switch on a single string field...

When you see:

`crv: 'Ed25519'` ...You know you will be using `alg: EdDSA`.

When you see:

`crv: 'secp256k1'` ...You know you will be using `alg: ES256K`.


When you see:

`crv: 'P256'` ...You know you will be using `alg: ES256`.

I think we want `alg: 'CRYDI3'` or `pset: 'CRYDI3'`

But not both in the JWK.

comments.author: OR13
comments.body: This issue is also blocking out ability to register multicodecs since we need a single name for the concept of "crv" in order to do that.... which in turn blocks possibility of registering a did key representation.

comments.author: mprorock
comments.body: resolved to go alg path, but also allow for pset to express details on parameters.  specifically, `alg` is a MUST, in the form of `alg: 'CRYDI3'` and `pset` is a MAY

issues.title: Rename draft to conform to IETF naming conventions
issues.author: selfissued
issues.body:
To submit to the COSE working group, the draft name must be of the form `draft-<lastname>-cose-<draftname>`. I'd suggest the identifier `draft-prorock-cose-post-quantum-signatures` or something similar.

Note that both the filename and the draft name in the markdown need to be changed.  The draft name in the markdown should become  `draft-prorock-cose-post-quantum-signatures-00`.

comments.author: mprorock
comments.body: Keeping this open until we shift from `-latest` to `-00`

comments.author: brownoxford
comments.body:
We are using https://github.com/martinthomson/i-d-template to manage the editing of this draft, and it requires `-latest` or linting fails.

@selfissued, is the `-00` suffix a hard requirement instead of `-latest`?

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
tooling should be handling this automatically.

See https://github.com/json-web-proofs/json-web-proofs/blob/main/.github/workflows/publish.yml

and yes, you don't ask for folks to review `latest` because it changes.... `00` is a requirement.

comments.author: brownoxford
comments.body:
@selfissued I've reviewed the repository that Orie linked above, and confirmed that it is using the same tooling that we are for managing the editing of the draft, and that it also uses draft naming in the markdown with "-latest" suffix.

Can you comment on the `draft-prorock-cose-post-quantum-signatures-latest` naming vs. `draft-prorock-cose-post-quantum-signatures-00` that you requested above?

issues.title: Submit drafts before march 7th
issues.author: OR13
issues.body:
See the mailing list submissions for the format examples:

- https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-looker-cose-bls-key-representations/

issues.title: Should we be using OKP for the "kty"
issues.author: mprorock
issues.body: Key type could very well be OKP in this case and we should seriously consider it - group should get feedback in on this

comments.author: cyberphone
comments.body:
I would very much recommend against overloading OKP because that breaks existing OKP software.  OKP is fine but in the end you still have to convert it to the platform's own representation of keys.  If you take Java, Oracle have after 5 years managed creating such interfaces for Ed25519/Ed448 and X25519/X448.  These wont's change.  Creating new Java key types is the way to go and can be done without external involvement.

I believe this applies to most platforms although the details differs.

An example showing the ugliness of existing OKP solutions due to the fact that Oracle never bothered with OKP:
https://github.com/cyberphone/openkeystore/blob/master/library/src/org/webpki/crypto/OkpSupport.java

You have a chance creating more functional interfaces where `Key`, `PrivateKey`, and `PublicKey` for the respective algorithms have direct counterparts to their external representation, not requiring folks do ASN.1!

If possible (and applicable), I would at an early stage consider PKIX and PEM formats as well.

By having unique key types you also don't run into clashes with cryptographic providers.  Crypto libraries will be able to see that this is an XYZ key which requires calling a special driver.

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
![Screen Shot 2022-03-20 at 4 18 39 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8295856/159186356-18694536-5ba7-4a7b-aec9-3d19a7cadf69.png)

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8037#section-2

Basically, we can't use OKP because of the MUST for use with `crv` which is not relevant to us.

comments.author: cyberphone
comments.body:
RFC 8037 also uses polymorphic (generic) signature algorithms which I once brought up as a mistake which much later was echoed by one of the COSE WG co-chairs.

RFC 8037 should IMO be regarded as "frozen" and dedicated to the four algorithms it is currently known to support.  As such it works OK.   Comparable definitions from the ASN.1/X.509 world have adopted an approach which separates algorithms classes from each other.  This is compatible (albeit in a somewhat quirky way), with current COSE/JOSE definitions.  Overloading existing definitions would break this compatibility as well as associated support code.

That is, even if a new crypto system has identical parameters to an existing ditto, it should get a separate name space in order to permit safe and simple integration in supporting libraries and APIs.  In a "pluggable" crypto architecture, this could potentially be done without a touching a single line of code.  The most recent version of OpenSSL supports pluggable crypto providers.  The system used in Java could be fitted with integral support for JOSE/COSE keys without disrupting any of its current features.   Eventually you could end-up with cool stuff like:

    KeyPair keyPair = new KeyTranslator().import(_byte-array | stream_);

You would not even have to specify if the key-pair is provided as PKCS \#8/PEM, COSE, or JOSE since the basic format can be detected by simple "sniffing".

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
```
KeyPair keyPair = new KeyTranslator().import(byte-array | stream);
```

^ this is basically how multi codec works.

issues.title: Evidence that kty: PQK + alg is the path forward
issues.author: OR13
issues.body:
I did yet another JWT / CWT library integration with DIDs this weekend, I wrote the same "alg" detection code I have written every time I have reached for JOSE and COSE...

https://github.com/transmute-industries/verifiable-data/blob/main/packages/did-jose-cose/src/keyPairToAlg.ts

Just so its clear this isn't just me...

https://github.com/panva/jose/blob/6b5e6acbe4c380b6b1142e3fbfc33a664552a272/src/jwks/local.ts#L18

https://github.com/panva/jose/blob/80741cb32a5b34d40c89478e2fdd0b4116eda546/src/runtime/node/node_key.ts#L21

Pretty much every JOSE / COSE library has some mapping like this because:

1. alg is optional in JWK
2. importing a key without specifying an `alg` makes it impossible to know which signature scheme the key is supposed to be used with.

Let's say you want to use an off the shelf JOSE  library to sign with a spec legal JWK private key....

You will be doing something like this:

```ts
import { keyPairToAlg } from "../../keyPairToAlg";
import { CompactJwt, PrivateKeyJwk, Header, Payload } from "types";
const jose = require("jose");
export const sign = async (
  header: Header,
  payload: Payload,
  privateKeyJwk: PrivateKeyJwk
): Promise<CompactJwt> => {
  const alg = keyPairToAlg(privateKeyJwk);
  const jwt = await new jose.SignJWT({ ...payload })
    .setProtectedHeader({ alg, ...header })
    .setIssuedAt(payload.iat)
    .setIssuer(payload.iss)
    .setAudience(payload.aud)
    .setExpirationTime(payload.exp)
    .sign(await jose.importJWK({ alg, ...privateKeyJwk }));
  return jwt;
};
```

If `privateKeyJwk` had an alg (even though its optional, you are good).

If `privateKeyJwk` did not have an alg  (likely given its optional), you will be asking the caller to

1. "know the legal algs, and ask for the right one or get an error"
1. "have the library compute the legal alg from the key (as shown above)"

Both are a source of security bugs that can be catastrophic...

> In general, a single key shall be used for only one purpose (e.g., encryption, integrity
authentication, key wrapping, random bit generation, or digital signatures). 

> Cryptography can be rendered ineffective by the use of weak products, inappropriate algorithm
pairing, poor physical security, and the use of weak protocols. 


see also "5.6.4 Transitioning to New Algorithms and Key Sizes"... impossible to do with some spec legal JWK.

- https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-57pt1r4.pdf


The current spec legal interpretation of JOSE / COSE for `OKP and EC` `crv` + `alg` pairings violates security best practices.

Making `alg` optional was a mistake...  its not too late to fix this for post quantum keys.

issues.title: Dockerized Test Vector Generation
issues.author: OR13
issues.body:
We probably want a small dockerized cli for generating test vectors.

Something like what we have for https://github.com/decentralized-identity/JWS-Test-Suite

We would commit to source the configurations to generate and test implementations regardless of language.

We expose a top level generate and verify interface matrix'ed out over the supported implementations.

We require 2 to generate and 2 to verify per implementation to keep it is the spec.

We pull the IETF test vector tooling from https://github.com/json-web-proofs/json-web-proofs/pull/47

This ticket is done when test vectors are built and included for all intended registrations (all keys, all signatures, twice)

pulls.title: Replace "pset" with registered "alg"
pulls.author: OR13
pulls.body:
This PR attempts to reduce the complexity by using the `alg` field and avoiding registering a new term `pset` which does not generalize beyond dilithium.

This also aligns better with the specs that registered traditional ecdsa.

comments.body: note the abuse of the `alg` field here previously... its values did not match the signature values that we need to register... because of the pset part.

Note the simplification here.

see below the example of the JWS header:

```
"header": { "alg": "CRYDI3", "kid": "did:example:123#key-0" },
```

note the algorithm here contains the pset as suffix....but the original spec registered `alg` without the pset and with it... which was confusing.

pulls.title: chore: clean up static folder
pulls.author: brownoxford
pulls.body:
The following files have been removed
- static/draft-prorock-cose-post-quantum-signatures-00.html
- static/draft-prorock-cose-post-quantum-signatures-00.txt

The following are now available on gh-pages
- https://mesur-io.github.io/post-quantum-signatures/draft-prorock-cose-post-quantum-signatures-00.txt
- https://mesur-io.github.io/post-quantum-signatures/draft-prorock-cose-post-quantum-signatures-00.html

These were added by building the draft in the main branch, renaming the files with `-00` suffixes, then switching to the `gh-pages` branch and committing.

pulls.title: Remove computable xs and ds
pulls.author: OR13
pulls.body: since they can be computed from `x` and `d` and they are a source of faults... consider the case where `xs` was not computed correctly from `x`.
